title: Director
ai_summary: Paul M. Thompson is the Director of the Imaging Genetics Center at the University of Southern California. His research focuses on utilizing advanced neuroimaging techniques and machine learning methods to study neurodegenerative diseases, particularly Alzheimer's disease (AD) and Parkinson's disease. Thompson has developed and applied deep learning models and multimodal imaging analyses to predict disease progression, identify biomarkers, and improve clinical trial design. He also works on harmonizing imaging data across diverse cohorts, integrating genetic information, and advancing automated imaging biomarker standardization.

Alex Mihailidis' research focuses on the development and evaluation of technology-driven solutions to support older adults, particularly those with dementia, in maintaining independence and improving quality of life. His work emphasizes ambient assisted living (AAL) technologies, including AI-powered systems for guiding daily activities, monitoring behavioral symptoms, and assessing cognitive impairments. He explores machine learning approaches for personalized detection and intervention, integrating privacy-aware sensing and multimodal data from wearable and ambient sensors. Mihailidis’ contributions span from designing intelligent environments to creating tools that reduce caregiver burden and enable early identification of frailty and cognitive decline.

title: Program Director, Healthcare Practice and Survivorship
ai_summary: Wendy Moyle is the Program Director for Healthcare Practice and Survivorship at the Menzies Health Institute Queensland, Griffith University. Her research focuses on the use of social and companion robots, such as PARO and humanoid telepresence devices, to support emotional well-being, engagement, and quality of life in older adults, particularly those living with dementia. Moyle has conducted numerous clinical trials and qualitative studies evaluating the effectiveness, feasibility, and staff perceptions of these robotic interventions in aged care settings. Her work also explores the use of technology-assisted methods, including automated pain assessment, to enhance care for people with dementia.

Dinggang Shen’s research focuses on the application of advanced machine learning, particularly deep learning, to medical imaging for the diagnosis and prognosis of neurological diseases such as Alzheimer's disease (AD), mild cognitive impairment (MCI), and dementia. His work involves developing novel computational models that integrate multimodal neuroimaging data—such as MRI, PET, and functional MRI—with genetic and clinical information to improve disease classification and progression prediction. Shen has also contributed to methods for enhancing image quality, such as synthesizing high-quality PET images from low-dose scans using generative adversarial networks. Additionally, his research explores brain connectivity patterns underlying cognitive impairment and leverages spatial-temporal neural networks for identifying disease-related brain regions and forecasting disease progression.

title: Professor
ai_summary: Dympna Casey is a Professor at the School of Nursing & Midwifery, National University of Ireland Galway, whose research focuses on the use and implementation of assistive technologies in dementia care. Her work extensively explores the development, usability, and ethical considerations of technologies such as social robots, pet robots, and virtual reality to support psychosocial health and quality of life for people living with dementia. She investigates barriers and facilitators to deploying these technologies in real-world settings, employing frameworks like the Consolidated Framework of Implementation Research to guide practical implementation strategies. Her research emphasizes stakeholder involvement, cost-effectiveness, and context-sensitive adoption of innovative care technologies within nursing and residential care environments.

title: Professor of Radiology
ai_summary: Clifford R. Jack, Professor of Radiology at Mayo Medical School, focuses his research on neuroimaging and biomarker development for Alzheimer's disease (AD) and related neurodegenerative disorders. His work involves advanced imaging techniques such as MRI, PET, and diffusion tensor imaging, combined with machine learning approaches to improve early diagnosis, subtype differentiation, and prediction of disease progression. He has contributed to the development of models that integrate multi-modal longitudinal data and artificial intelligence to enhance detection of AD pathology and optimize clinical trial design. His research aims to enable earlier intervention and precision medicine strategies in neurodegenerative diseases.

title: Professor
ai_summary: John C. Morris is a Professor of Pathology and Immunology at Washington University School of Medicine whose research focuses on Alzheimer's disease (AD) and related neurodegenerative conditions. His work employs advanced machine learning, neuroimaging, and multi-omics approaches to understand the molecular, pathological, and clinical heterogeneity of AD. Morris has contributed to identifying disease biomarkers, elucidating disease progression patterns, and improving prediction models for cognitive decline and conversion from mild cognitive impairment to AD. His studies also explore the role of tau pathology, amyloid deposition, and synaptic dysfunction in AD, aiming to advance early diagnosis, patient stratification, and targeted therapeutic strategies.

title: Asst
ai_summary: Christos Davatzikos is an Assistant Professor at the University of Pennsylvania whose research focuses on advanced neuroimaging analysis and machine learning applications in neuroscience. His work includes developing quantitative imaging biomarkers for brain aging, neurodegenerative diseases, and neuropsychiatric disorders, utilizing methods such as generative adversarial networks and radiomics. Davatzikos has contributed to improving the accuracy of brain function measurements, predicting disease progression, and characterizing genetic and structural brain heterogeneity. His research spans topics such as Alzheimer’s disease, white matter changes, psychosis risk, and brain aging in conditions like type 1 diabetes.

title: Associate Professor of Behavioural Sciences
ai_summary: Cindy Jones is an Associate Professor of Behavioural Sciences in the Faculty of Health Sciences & Medicine at Bond University. Her research primarily focuses on the use of social and companion robots, such as PARO, to improve the psychological, emotional, and behavioral well-being of older adults living with dementia, particularly in long-term care settings. She has investigated the effects of these interventions on outcomes including pain management, depression, loneliness, engagement, and quality of life, often employing randomized controlled trials and mixed-methods approaches. Additionally, her work explores innovative technologies like the PainChek app for assessing pain through facial expressions, contributing to improved care practices for individuals with dementia.

title: Professor and Director, Center for Neuroimaging and Indiana Alzheimer's Disease Research Center
ai_summary: Andrew J. Saykin is a Professor and Director of the Center for Neuroimaging and Indiana Alzheimer's Disease Research Center in Radiology and Imaging Sciences at Indiana University School of Medicine. His research focuses on applying advanced machine learning and deep learning techniques to neuroimaging and biomarker data for early detection, classification, and progression prediction of Alzheimer's disease (AD). He investigates multimodal approaches combining neuroimaging, fluid biomarkers, and genetic data to identify distinct disease subtypes, metabolic alterations, and molecular signatures associated with AD pathogenesis. Additionally, his work includes the development of predictive models for clinical trial enrichment and improving diagnostic accuracy through large-scale data integration and innovative imaging methodologies.

title: Professor and Head of Department
org: UCL Institute of Neurology, University College London
ai_summary: Nick C. Fox is Professor and Head of Department of Neurodegenerative Disease at the UCL Institute of Neurology, University College London. His research focuses on the use of advanced neuroimaging techniques and machine learning methods to improve diagnosis, subtyping, and prediction in Alzheimer's disease and related dementias. He has developed computational models, including support vector machines and deep learning frameworks, to analyze structural and functional brain imaging data for early detection, differentiation of dementia types, and patient stratification. Additionally, his work explores biomarkers of disease progression and cognitive decline, contributing to the understanding of neuroanatomical changes in both preclinical and symptomatic stages of neurodegenerative disorders.

Michael W. Weiner's research focuses on neurodegenerative diseases, particularly Alzheimer's disease (AD) and frontotemporal dementia, using advanced neuroimaging and computational methods. His work has explored brain network connectivity changes, biomarker development, and disease subtyping through machine learning to improve diagnosis and prognosis. He has made significant contributions to understanding patterns of brain aging, cognitive decline, and heterogeneity in disease progression by integrating multimodal imaging, fluid biomarkers, and deep learning models. Additionally, he has played a key role in large-scale initiatives like ADNI to develop and validate biomarkers that enhance clinical trial design and inclusivity.

title: Scientific Director
ai_summary: Luigi Ferrucci is the Scientific Director at the National Institute on Aging (NIA) Intramural Research Program, specializing in aging biology and geriatric medicine. His research focuses on the complex biological mechanisms underlying frailty, immunosenescence, and the aging process, employing approaches from molecular biology to systems biology and machine learning. Ferrucci has explored biomarkers for frailty and cellular senescence, and investigated the integration of biological aging concepts into clinical practice. His work also includes studying Alzheimer's disease heterogeneity and developing predictive models for personalized physiological age and aging-related health outcomes.

Stefan Teipel's research focuses on the application of advanced neuroimaging techniques and machine learning approaches to understand and predict the progression of Alzheimer's disease (AD) and mild cognitive impairment (MCI). He has contributed to developing data mining frameworks and convolutional neural network (CNN) models that analyze MRI and diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) data to identify brain atrophy patterns and connectivity changes associated with AD. His work explores the use of functional and structural brain connectivity as biomarkers, and examines how artificial intelligence can improve diagnostic accuracy and model interpretability. Additionally, Teipel investigates the integration of multimodal data, including neuropsychological and biomarker information, to enhance prediction of cognitive decline and support clinical decision-making.

title: A.W. and Mary Margaret Clausen Distinguished Professor
ai_summary: Bruce L. Miller is the A.W. and Mary Margaret Clausen Distinguished Professor of Neurology at the University of California San Francisco. His research focuses on neurodegenerative diseases, particularly frontotemporal dementia, primary progressive aphasia, and corticobasal degeneration, with an emphasis on clinical characterization, neuroanatomical correlates, and biomarker development. He has also contributed to understanding neural network dysfunction in dementia and advancing technology-based approaches for improving care in Alzheimer's disease and related disorders. Additionally, Miller explores global brain health initiatives, integrating technological innovation and diplomacy to enhance diagnosis and care worldwide.

Arthur W. Toga’s research focuses on the use of advanced neuroimaging and machine learning techniques to understand neurodegenerative diseases, particularly Alzheimer’s disease (AD). His work includes developing computational models to identify distinct disease subtypes, predict progression from mild cognitive impairment to AD, and map brain aging patterns using multimodal imaging biomarkers. Toga has contributed to large-scale initiatives like the Alzheimer’s Disease Neuroimaging Initiative (ADNI), enhancing biomarker validation, improving clinical trial design, and advancing the study of genetic and pathological heterogeneity in AD. His research aims to enable precision medicine approaches through improved diagnosis, prognosis, and patient stratification.

title: Chief Medical Officer (CMO), Senior Vice President
ai_summary: Harald Hampel is Chief Medical Officer and Senior Vice President of the Neurology Business Group at Eisai Inc., with extensive research focused on Alzheimer's disease and related cognitive disorders. His work encompasses the study of cholinergic system dysfunction in Alzheimer's, advanced neuroimaging and machine learning techniques for early diagnosis and prediction of disease progression, and the integration of multimodal biomarkers for precision medicine approaches. He has contributed to the development and validation of quantitative imaging standards and explored the role of genetics, neuropsychology, and digital health in improving diagnosis and treatment. Additionally, Hampel advocates for innovative strategies like liquid biopsy and artificial intelligence to enable personalized therapeutics in neurodegenerative diseases.

title: Associate Professor
ai_summary: Filippo Cavallo is an Associate Professor of Industrial Engineering at the University of Florence. His research focuses on the development and evaluation of robotics and information and communication technologies (ICT) to support older adults and people with neurodegenerative diseases, such as dementia and Parkinson's disease. He investigates user acceptance, usability, and the integration of assistive robotic systems to promote independent living, social inclusion, and health monitoring. Additionally, his work explores cloud robotics, social robot human-interaction models, and technological interventions to enhance quality of life and caregiver support in real-world settings.

Frederik Barkhof’s research focuses on the application of advanced neuroimaging techniques, particularly MRI, to the study of neurological diseases such as Alzheimer's disease, multiple sclerosis, and vascular cognitive impairment. He has contributed to developing and validating imaging biomarkers, including hippocampal volumetry and brain volumetric harmonization methods, to improve diagnosis, disease monitoring, and prediction of progression. Barkhof’s work also explores the integration of machine learning and explainable artificial intelligence in neuroimaging, aiming to enhance the accuracy and interpretability of automated dementia diagnosis and prognosis. His research additionally addresses the characterization of brain network alterations through resting-state functional MRI and the quantification of small vessel disease-related brain changes.

title: Scientific Director
ai_summary: Agustín Ibáñez is the Scientific Director at Universidad Adolfo Ibañez and the Latin American Brain Health Institute (BrainLat). His research focuses on brain health and neurodegenerative diseases, particularly Alzheimer's disease and frontotemporal dementia, employing advanced machine learning and neuroimaging techniques to improve diagnosis and understand disease mechanisms across diverse populations. He investigates cognitive aging, brain resilience factors such as bilingualism, and social determinants affecting brain health in Latin America and globally. Additionally, he promotes innovative, interdisciplinary approaches including brain health diplomacy and immersive initiatives to enhance dementia care, reduce stigma, and address health inequities.

Rhoda Au's research focuses on applying advanced machine learning and deep learning techniques to improve the diagnosis, prediction, and understanding of Alzheimer's disease and related dementias. Her work integrates multimodal data sources including neuroimaging, clinical assessments, plasma biomarkers, and speech analysis to develop interpretable AI models capable of early detection, differential diagnosis, and progression prediction of cognitive impairment. She explores precision health approaches, including digital biomarkers derived from wearable devices and speech, to identify subpopulations and refine intervention strategies. Additionally, her studies emphasize model generalizability across diverse cohorts and alignment of AI findings with neuropathological evidence to support clinical applicability.

Philip Scheltens is a researcher specializing in the study of Alzheimer's disease and other dementias, focusing on brain network alterations, neuroimaging biomarkers, and diagnostic techniques. His work employs advanced methods such as graph theoretical analysis of EEG/MEG data, visual rating scales in MRI, and multiplex network analysis to identify patterns of brain connectivity disruption and atrophy in dementia. He has contributed to developing standardized imaging protocols and computational approaches to improve diagnosis and prognosis in Alzheimer's disease. Additionally, Scheltens advocates for the implementation of Brain Health Services aimed at early risk profiling and personalized prevention strategies to reduce dementia incidence at the population level.

title: Visiting Professor
ai_summary: J. M. Górriz, Visiting Professor of Psychiatry at the University of Cambridge, conducts research focused on computer-aided diagnosis systems for neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's. His work extensively employs machine learning and deep learning techniques, including convolutional neural networks and nonnegative matrix factorization, applied to neuroimaging data from modalities like MRI, PET, and SPECT. He also explores the integration of cognitive testing data with imaging, and advances in explainable AI, to improve early detection and classification accuracy of cognitive impairments. Additionally, Górriz contributes to advancing AI applications in neuroscience by summarizing state-of-the-art methods and addressing challenges in clinical implementation.

title: Professor
ai_summary: Yudong Zhang is a Professor at the School of Informatics, University of Leicester, whose research focuses on the development and application of machine learning and deep learning techniques for medical imaging and neurological disease diagnosis. His work extensively explores advanced neural network models, including extreme learning machines and convolutional neural networks, to improve the accuracy and efficiency of brain image analysis for conditions such as Alzheimer's disease and cerebral microbleeds. Zhang has contributed to the integration of optimization algorithms and novel network architectures to enhance diagnostic systems, particularly leveraging MRI data for early disease detection. Additionally, he has surveyed and advanced deep learning methodologies in neuroscience, emphasizing their application to clinical diagnostics and automated disease identification.

Bruno Vellas is a researcher focused on aging, neurodegenerative diseases, and healthy longevity, with numerous contributions to Alzheimer's disease and dementia research. His work encompasses large-scale multicenter MRI studies to understand brain changes in aging and dementia, including the implementation of deep learning techniques for imaging analysis. He has also contributed significantly to geroscience, emphasizing the identification of biomarkers of aging and the development of integrated care models like the WHO ICOPE program to maintain intrinsic capacity and autonomy in older adults. Additionally, Vellas leads translational research initiatives, such as the INSPIRE platform, aiming to combine biological, clinical, and digital data to promote precision health and preventive strategies for healthy aging.

Babak Taati's research focuses on the application of computer vision and machine learning technologies to support the assessment and monitoring of health in older adults, particularly those with dementia. His work includes developing automated systems for detecting mild cognitive impairment, assessing gait and fall risk through video-based ambient monitoring, and analyzing facial expressions for pain and facial palsy. He explores the use of unobtrusive sensing technologies and pose estimation algorithms to extract clinically relevant metrics, aiming to enable early detection and continuous monitoring of physical and cognitive health issues. His studies also address challenges in adapting machine learning models to diverse clinical populations to improve diagnostic accuracy and assessment fairness.

Javier Ramírez's research primarily focuses on developing advanced computer-aided diagnosis (CAD) systems for neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer's Disease (AD) using machine learning and deep learning techniques. His work involves the analysis of multimodal brain imaging data, including MRI, PET, and SPECT, often combined with neuropsychological assessments to enhance early detection accuracy. He explores methods such as deep belief networks, convolutional neural networks, non-negative matrix factorization, and support vector machines to extract discriminative features and improve classification performance. Additionally, he investigates the application of explainable AI and data fusion approaches to better understand and interpret diagnostic patterns in clinical contexts.

title: Regents Professor and Huie-Rogers Chair
ai_summary: Diane J. Cook is a Regents Professor and Huie-Rogers Chair at Washington State University whose research focuses on the development of machine learning and pervasive computing technologies for smart environments. Her work extensively explores activity recognition, monitoring, and prediction within smart homes to assess and support the health and functional independence of aging individuals. She has advanced methods for detecting cognitive and physical health changes through unobtrusive sensing, integrating multimodal behavioral data, and employing novel forecasting techniques including large language models. Her research also emphasizes creating intelligent systems that provide anticipatory support for everyday functioning and early detection of age-related disorders.

Shuihua Wang‎ is a researcher specializing in the development and application of machine learning and deep learning techniques for medical image analysis, particularly brain MRI. His work includes advancement of algorithms such as extreme learning machines, convolutional neural networks, and support vector machines, applied to tasks like detection of Alzheimer's disease, cerebral microbleeds, and abnormal brain pathology. Wang has focused on optimizing feature extraction, classifier training, and parameter selection methods to improve diagnostic accuracy and efficiency. His research also surveys recent deep learning developments in neurodegenerative disease detection, contributing comprehensive reviews and novel hybrid approaches for automated medical diagnosis.

org: National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology
ai_summary: Takanori Shibata's research centers on the development and application of therapeutic robots, particularly the seal-shaped robot PARO, designed to support mental healthcare for elderly individuals, including those with dementia. His work demonstrates how interaction with PARO can improve mood, reduce stress, enhance social interaction, and alleviate behavioral symptoms in elderly care settings. Shibata has also explored the use of PARO in both institutional and home environments, emphasizing the robot's role in augmenting familial care and reducing caregiver burden. His studies include clinical trials and observational research that assess the psychosocial and physiological effects of robot-assisted therapy.

title: Scientific director
ai_summary: Wiesje M. van der Flier is the scientific director of Neurology and the Alzheimer Center at Amsterdam UMC Location VUmc. Her research focuses on understanding the neuropathological mechanisms and clinical diagnostics of Alzheimer's disease (AD) and other dementias through advanced neuroimaging, machine learning, and network analysis methods. She has contributed to studies on brain network alterations in AD, the role of cognitive and brain reserve in disease progression, and the development of imaging biomarkers and classifiers to distinguish AD from other neurodegenerative disorders. Additionally, she leads clinical investigations into novel diagnostic tools such as tau-PET imaging and the integration of multimodal biomarkers to improve diagnostic accuracy and patient management in real-world memory clinic settings.

org: Azienda Ospedaliera Nazionale SS. Antonio e Biagio e Cesare Arrigo
ai_summary: Enzo Grossi's research focuses on applying advanced artificial neural network (ANN) methodologies to neurodegenerative and neurodevelopmental disorders, particularly Alzheimer's disease (AD), mild cognitive impairment (MCI), dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB), and Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD). He has developed novel computational models like Auto-Contractive Maps (Auto-CM) and IFAST to analyze complex biomedical data, enabling improved diagnosis, prognosis, and differentiation of these conditions. His work integrates biochemical, cognitive, neuroimaging, and electrophysiological data using nonlinear analysis and machine learning to uncover intricate relationships among genetic, environmental, and clinical factors. Grossi’s studies also explore the impact of lifestyle, immunological, and oxidative stress markers on disease progression, aiming to inform personalized and preventive healthcare strategies.

title: Team Leader
ai_summary: Mihoko Otake is the Team Leader at the Center for Advanced Intelligence Project at RIKEN, focusing on the application of artificial intelligence and machine learning to cognitive health in older adults. Her research explores innovative digital biomarkers for early detection and monitoring of mild cognitive impairment and dementia using EEG, eye-tracking, and behavioral data. She has developed AI-driven interventions, including robotic moderated conversation programs and wearable technologies, aimed at improving cognitive function and preventing decline. Otake’s work integrates cross-cultural studies and advanced data analysis methods to create accessible, non-invasive tools for cognitive assessment and intervention in aging populations.

title: Joy Chambers-Grundy Professor of Brain Science; Director, Chambers-Gundy Center for Transformative Neuroscience; Co-Director, Pam Quirk Brain Health and Biomarker Laboratory
unit: School of Integrated Health Sciences / Department of Brain Health
ai_summary: Jeffrey L. Cummings is the Joy Chambers-Grundy Professor of Brain Science and Director of the Chambers-Gundy Center for Transformative Neuroscience, as well as Co-Director of the Pam Quirk Brain Health and Biomarker Laboratory at the University of Nevada Las Vegas. His research focuses on neurodegenerative diseases, particularly Alzheimer's disease (AD) and frontotemporal dementia, emphasizing drug development, biomarker discovery, and the underlying biological mechanisms of these conditions. He investigates clinical trial design, disease-modifying therapies, and the application of artificial intelligence and precision medicine to accelerate AD therapeutic development. Additionally, his work explores sex differences in brain connectivity and advocates for enhancing brain health capital in late life.

title: Responsabile
ai_summary: Paolo Maria Rossini, Responsabile of Neuroscienze e Neuroriabilitazione at IRCCS San Raffaele Pisana, focuses his research on neurophysiology and neurorehabilitation, particularly using techniques like transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) and electroencephalography (EEG) to study brain connectivity and plasticity. His work extensively explores brain network analysis through graph theory and machine learning to investigate aging, stroke recovery, and neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's disease (AD) and mild cognitive impairment (MCI). He is involved in developing non-invasive, cost-effective biomarkers and AI-based tools for early diagnosis and prediction of dementia progression. Rossini’s research also emphasizes the integration of neurophysiological data with neuropsychological and biological markers for personalized intervention strategies.

title: Professor
ai_summary: Professor Magda Tsolaki, affiliated with the School of Medicine at Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, conducts research focused on dementia, Alzheimer's disease, and mild cognitive impairment (MCI). Her work spans the development and evaluation of assistive technologies, machine learning, and neuroimaging techniques for early diagnosis and monitoring of cognitive decline. She has contributed to studies on deep learning applications in medical imaging, EEG and plasma biomarkers for AD detection, and the implementation of digital biomarkers from smartphone data. Additionally, she investigates cognitive and emotional impairments in neurodegenerative diseases and emphasizes multidisciplinary approaches integrating clinical practice and technological innovation.

title: Médicin Responsable
unit: Médicine Interne, Réhabilitation & Gériatrie et de Santé Mentale & Psychiatrie
ai_summary: Giovanni B. Frisoni, affiliated with Médicin Responsable, Médicine Interne, Réhabilitation & Gériatrie et de Santé Mentale & Psychiatrie at Hôpitaux Universitaires de Genève, focuses his research on neurodegenerative diseases, particularly Alzheimer's disease. His work explores advanced imaging biomarkers, machine learning techniques for disease subtyping and progression, and metabolic and structural brain changes linked to cognitive decline. He has contributed to developing standardized approaches for imaging metrics and to understanding the neural basis of cognitive resilience. Additionally, he investigates predictive models for amyloid pathology and the potential of blood-based biomarkers in early diagnosis and personalized medicine.

title: Director
ai_summary: David A. Bennett is the Director of the Rush Alzheimer's Disease Center at Rush University Medical Center. His research focuses on the pathological and molecular mechanisms underlying Alzheimer's disease (AD) and related dementias, with particular attention to early detection, biomarker development, and the heterogeneity of clinical progression. He integrates longitudinal clinical data, neuropathology, and advanced molecular techniques including multi-omics and machine learning to identify novel biomarkers and subtypes of AD. Bennett's work also explores cognitive and motor resilience, aiming to uncover factors that modulate disease impact and progression in aging populations.

title: Head of Innovation and Research
ai_summary: Francesco Giuliani is Head of Innovation and Research at Casa Sollievo della Sofferenza, focusing on the development and validation of assistive technologies and ICT solutions for elderly populations, particularly those with dementia. His work involves designing social robots like MARIO to enhance social engagement, resilience, and quality of life for people with cognitive impairments. He also contributes to large-scale eHealth initiatives such as the H2020 GATEKEEPER project, aiming to create interoperable digital health platforms for aging populations across Europe and Asia. Additionally, Giuliani’s research addresses technology usability, acceptance, and integration in healthcare, including rapid deployment of assistive technologies during the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: Professor; Chief, Cognitive Neuroscience Division
ai_summary: Yaakov Stern is a Professor and Chief of the Cognitive Neuroscience Division in Neurology at Columbia University Medical Center. His research focuses on the cognitive and neural mechanisms underlying aging, Alzheimer’s disease, and dementia, with particular emphasis on cognitive reserve and how individual differences modulate clinical outcomes. Stern’s work integrates neuroimaging, epidemiology, and machine learning to improve understanding of early detection, risk prediction, and the interplay between cognition, brain function, and mobility across the adult lifespan. He also investigates ethnoracial factors in dementia research and the dynamic brain connectivity patterns supporting cognitive-motor functions.

title: Dirigente Psicologo
ai_summary: Grazia D’Onofrio, Dirigente Psicologo at the Clinical Psychology Service of the Health Department at Ospedale Casa Sollievo della Sofferenza, focuses her research on the use of information and communication technologies (ICT) and socially assistive robots to support older adults, particularly those with dementia. Her work includes evaluating robotic companions like MARIO and Pepper for their effects on cognitive, emotional, and social well-being, as well as developing models for enhancing human-robot interaction. She investigates the acceptability, usability, and efficacy of these technologies in real-world settings to promote independence, social engagement, and quality of life. Additionally, her studies explore emotion recognition, user profiling, and the deployment of assistive technologies to support caregiving and healthcare delivery for aging populations.

Jesse Hoey's research focuses on the development and evaluation of intelligent technologies, including artificial intelligence and socially assistive robots, to support older adults with dementia and their caregivers. His work explores autonomous systems that aid daily living activities, such as handwashing, and emphasizes emotional alignment between users and social robots through computational models like Affect Control Theory. He also investigates the ethical and social implications of AI systems analyzing human emotions. Additionally, he contributes to summarizing technology domains in dementia care, advocating for holistic approaches that enhance independence, engagement, and quality of life.

John Q. Trojanowski's research focuses on neurodegenerative diseases, particularly Alzheimer's disease (AD) and related tauopathies, exploring their molecular, genetic, and neuropathological underpinnings. His work integrates neuroimaging, neuropathology, and advanced computational methods to characterize disease progression, heterogeneity, and biomarkers, with a strong emphasis on tau pathology, gene expression changes with aging, and identification of novel genetic loci implicated in neurodegeneration. Trojanowski has contributed to understanding cortical and subcortical atrophy patterns across diverse neurodegenerative syndromes, as well as the development of frameworks for precision diagnostics and clinical trials. His research spans from molecular pathology and genetic association studies to large-scale biomarker initiatives like the Alzheimer’s Disease Neuroimaging Initiative (ADNI), aiming to inform disease mechanisms and improve clinical outcomes.

Jonathan D. Rohrer's research focuses on neurodegenerative diseases, particularly frontotemporal dementia (FTD), primary progressive aphasia (PPA), and atypical parkinsonian syndromes. He applies advanced neuroimaging techniques, machine learning methods, and molecular biomarkers to improve disease classification, early diagnosis, and patient stratification. His work includes developing data-driven models to identify distinct disease subtypes and progression stages, as well as utilizing multimodal data to distinguish between overlapping clinical syndromes. Additionally, Rohrer contributes to large-scale data platforms and advances biomarker discovery for practical clinical use in neurodegenerative disorders.

Jason D. Warren's research focuses on neurodegenerative diseases, particularly frontotemporal dementia and Alzheimer's disease, exploring their clinical, neuroanatomical, and molecular heterogeneity. He employs advanced machine learning techniques and network-based models to identify distinct disease subtypes and progression patterns from neuroimaging data. His work also investigates the neural mechanisms underlying deficits in socio-emotional processing, music perception, and degraded speech comprehension in dementia syndromes. Additionally, Warren examines the social brain's role in art perception, linking it to mental health and neurological conditions.

title: Associate Professor in Neuroimage Analysis
ai_summary: James H. Cole is an Associate Professor in Neuroimage Analysis, Computer Science at University College London. His research focuses on applying machine learning and neuroimaging to understand brain aging, neurological diseases, and cognitive decline. He has developed brain-predicted age biomarkers from structural MRI data to study aging processes, traumatic brain injury, Down syndrome, and stroke outcomes. Additionally, he explores explainable artificial intelligence for improving dementia diagnosis and prognosis, and works with large-scale clinical imaging datasets to enable real-world applications of neuroimaging biomarkers for brain and mental health.

title: Professor
ai_summary: Henrik Zetterberg is a Professor in the Department of Psychiatry and Neurochemistry at the University of Gothenburg. His research focuses on neurodegenerative diseases, particularly Alzheimer’s disease, exploring the molecular and biochemical underpinnings through proteomic analysis of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). He has contributed to identifying novel biomarkers linked to synaptic dysfunction and neurodegeneration, improving early diagnosis and prognosis of cognitive decline. Zetterberg's work also encompasses refining disease classification and understanding pathological hallmarks to inform personalized therapeutic strategies.

David J. Llewellyn's research focuses on dementia and Alzheimer's disease, exploring risk factors, early detection, and prevention strategies. He has investigated the role of vitamin D and socioeconomic status in dementia risk, emphasizing the importance of biomarker identification and modifiable lifestyle factors. His work extensively employs artificial intelligence and machine learning to improve dementia risk prediction, biomarker discovery, and precision medicine approaches. Additionally, Llewellyn advocates for new Brain Health Services that prioritize personalized risk profiling and interventions to reduce future dementia burden.

title: Geriatrician
unit: Geriatric Unit & Laboratory of Gerontology and Geriatrics, Department of Medical Sciences
ai_summary: Daniele Sancarlo is a geriatrician affiliated with the Geriatric Unit & Laboratory of Gerontology and Geriatrics, Department of Medical Sciences at Ospedale Casa Sollievo della Sofferenza. His research primarily focuses on the application of information and communication technologies, including socially assistive robots, to support older adults with dementia and frailty. Sancarlo has investigated the use of robotic companions like MARIO and Pepper to enhance social engagement, cognitive assessment, and quality of life in dementia patients, as well as to support caregivers. Additionally, his work explores advanced human-robot interaction models, emotion recognition in social robots, and the deployment of assistive technologies to promote healthy and active aging.

title: Assitant Professor (RTDA)
ai_summary: Laura Fiorini is an Assistant Professor (RTDA) at the Dipartimento di Ingegneria Industriale, Università degli Studi di Firenze, specializing in the development and evaluation of assistive robotics and information and communication technologies for aging populations. Her research focuses on implementing cloud robotics, telepresence, and socially assistive robots to support independent living, healthcare, and social inclusion among older adults, including those with mild cognitive impairment. Fiorini has contributed to designing personalized, scalable smart home and monitoring systems, as well as investigating human-robot interaction, emotion recognition, and usability aspects to enhance technology acceptance. Her work integrates multidisciplinary approaches to optimize the reliability, user experience, and clinical relevance of robotic solutions in real-world environments.

Massimo Filippi's research focuses on applying advanced imaging techniques and artificial intelligence to neurodegenerative diseases, particularly multiple sclerosis (MS), Alzheimer's disease (AD), and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). He has contributed to developing deep learning algorithms for diagnosing AD and predicting disease progression in MS using structural MRI data from large multicenter cohorts. Filippi's work also emphasizes the harmonization and analysis of multicenter MRI datasets to improve biomarker discovery and personalized treatment strategies. Additionally, he explores natural language processing tools to extract clinical data from unstructured medical records, facilitating large-scale data sharing and research in neurological disorders.

Daniel C. Alexander's research focuses on applying advanced machine learning and neuroimaging techniques to better understand neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's disease, frontotemporal dementia, and epilepsy. He has developed models like SuStaIn to identify distinct disease subtypes and progression patterns, enhancing patient stratification and prediction of disease evolution. His work also includes creating AI frameworks for analyzing medical imaging data, such as RETFound for retinal images and SynthSR for MRI scans with varied resolutions, aiming to improve diagnostic accuracy and data harmonization across diverse clinical settings. Overall, Alexander’s contributions lie in integrating computational methods with clinical data to uncover disease mechanisms and support precision medicine approaches.

title: Professsor
unit: Department of Mechanical, Aerospace, and Biomedical Engineering
ai_summary: Xiaopeng Zhao is a Professor in the Department of Mechanical, Aerospace, and Biomedical Engineering at the University of Tennessee. His research focuses on the development and application of robotics, brain-computer interfaces, and artificial intelligence to support cognitive training and dementia care. Zhao has contributed to creating robot-assisted cognitive training systems, social robots facilitating reminiscence and music therapies, and AI-driven caregiving simulations for persons living with dementia. His work aims to enhance the quality of life and independence of individuals with cognitive impairments through innovative technological solutions.

title: Distinguished University Professor and Director Tri-institutional Center for Translational Research in Neuroimaging and Data Science (TReNDS)
ai_summary: Vince D. Calhoun is a Distinguished University Professor and Director of the Tri-institutional Center for Translational Research in Neuroimaging and Data Science (TReNDS) at Georgia State University, with appointments in Psychology, Computer Science, and Neuroscience. His research focuses on neuroimaging methods to understand brain function and dysfunction in psychiatric and neurological disorders such as Alzheimer's disease and schizophrenia. He has extensively utilized advanced analytic techniques including independent component analysis, functional connectivity, and deep learning to study brain networks, develop biomarkers, and create normative models for disease characterization. His work also explores multi-modal data fusion and machine learning approaches to enhance the understanding and diagnosis of complex brain disorders.

Elizabeth Broadbent’s research focuses on the intersection of robotics, healthcare, and aging, particularly the use of social and assistive robots to support older adults, including those with mild cognitive impairment or dementia. Her work involves exploring user perceptions, acceptance, and the practical utility of healthcare robots in settings such as retirement villages and aged care facilities. She emphasizes participatory design, involving end-users and care experts to tailor robots for daily care, cognitive stimulation, companionship, and safety monitoring. Broadbent’s studies address both the technological development of healthcare robots and their social and emotional impacts on users and caregivers.

title: Daniel J Brennan MD Professor of Neurology
ai_summary: Beau M. Ances is the Daniel J Brennan MD Professor of Neurology, Radiology, and Biomedical Engineering at Washington University in Saint Louis. His research focuses on Alzheimer’s disease, utilizing advanced neuroimaging techniques, cerebrospinal fluid biomarkers, and machine learning to improve early diagnosis and understand disease progression. Ances has investigated the spatial distribution and spread of tau pathology, the role of the gut microbiome in preclinical Alzheimer's, and the comparative predictive power of various biomarkers for cognitive impairment. His work integrates multimodal data to better characterize Alzheimer’s disease pathology and identify individuals at risk.

title: Director, Alexander von Humboldt Professor for AI
unit: Institute for Artificial Intelligence and Informatics in Medicine
ai_summary: Daniel Rueckert is Director and Alexander von Humboldt Professor for AI at the Institute for Artificial Intelligence and Informatics in Medicine at the Technical University of Munich. His research focuses on developing advanced deep learning and image analysis methods for medical imaging, including brain lesion segmentation, anatomical shape analysis, and quality assessment of medical images. He has contributed to the quantification of brain changes related to neurological diseases using MRI and the analysis of retinal aging via generative models. Rueckert's work emphasizes interpretable models, efficient processing of volumetric data, and open sharing of validated tools for large-scale clinical and population studies.

title: Full Professor
org: École Nationale Supérieure de Techniques Avancées
ai_summary: Adriana Tapus is a Full Professor of Computer Science and System Engineering at École Nationale Supérieure de Techniques Avancées. Her research focuses on the development of socially assistive robotic systems designed to support elderly individuals, particularly those with mild cognitive impairments and dementia. She works on adaptive robot behaviors that personalize interactions through verbal and non-verbal communication, aiming to enhance motivation, cognitive stimulation, and companionship. Her projects include creating robotic platforms capable of health monitoring, complementary care, and social support to improve the quality of life for aging populations.

title: Lecturer in Occupational Therapy
ai_summary: Wei Qi Koh is a Lecturer in Occupational Therapy at the University of Queensland whose research focuses on the use and implementation of social robots and robotic pets to support the psychosocial health of older adults and people living with dementia. Their work systematically investigates barriers and facilitators to adopting these technologies in real-world settings, particularly nursing homes, using implementation science frameworks such as the Consolidated Framework of Implementation Research (CFIR). Wei Qi Koh also explores ethical considerations, usability, and stakeholder perspectives surrounding technology acceptance, and advocates for occupational therapists' involvement in the design and integration of socially assistive technologies to enhance meaningful social participation for people with dementia. Their studies include evaluating low-cost robotic pets, identifying practical strategies for clinical uptake, and fostering interdisciplinary collaboration to optimize technology relevance and accessibility.

Dag Aarsland's research primarily focuses on neurodegenerative diseases, particularly Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease dementia, and dementia with Lewy bodies. He has contributed to identifying synaptic protein changes linked to cognitive decline and explored neuroanatomical correlates of depressive symptoms in Alzheimer's patients. Aarsland has also been involved in developing and validating artificial intelligence and deep learning models for improving diagnosis and monitoring of dementia-related disorders using neuroimaging techniques. Additionally, his work addresses the implementation of digital and remote assessment technologies to enhance cognitive testing accessibility and management, especially in the context of ageing populations and challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic.

Susan M. Resnick’s research focuses on the neurobiological and neuroanatomical changes associated with aging, Alzheimer’s disease (AD), and related cognitive decline. She employs advanced neuroimaging techniques and machine learning methods to identify brain patterns linked to typical aging, AD pathology, and white matter disease, exploring their relationships with cognition and genetic risk factors such as APOE. Her work includes investigating environmental influences like air pollution on early memory decline and characterizing disease heterogeneity to improve precision diagnostics and prognostics. Resnick’s studies contribute to understanding the interplay between brain structure, molecular markers, and clinical outcomes across the continuum from asymptomatic aging to dementia.

title: Research Director - Laboratory Head
unit: ARAMIS Lab (ICM, CNRS, Inserm, Inria, Sorbonne Université)
ai_summary: Olivier Colliot is Research Director and Laboratory Head at the ARAMIS Lab (ICM, CNRS, Inserm, Inria, Sorbonne Université) affiliated with CNRS Délégation Paris B. His research focuses on the application of machine learning and deep learning techniques to neuroimaging and multimodal data for understanding, diagnosing, and predicting brain disorders such as Alzheimer's disease and multiple sclerosis. He has contributed to developing novel analytical methods for brain network analysis, disease progression prediction, and automated image processing. His work also addresses the integration of advanced computational models into clinical practice, emphasizing methodological rigor and interpretability.

title: Professor
org: King Fahd University of Petroleum and Minerals
ai_summary: Mufti Mahmud is a Professor of Information and Computer Science at King Fahd University of Petroleum and Minerals. His research focuses on the development and application of machine learning, deep learning, and explainable AI techniques for biomedical data analysis, particularly in neuroimaging and Alzheimer’s disease detection. He has extensively worked on multimodal data integration, AI-driven diagnostic models, and interpretable frameworks to enhance clinical decision support systems. His work also explores the comparative effectiveness of conventional and AI-based interventions for neurodegenerative diseases, aiming to improve patient care and disease prognosis.

Richard J. Perrin's research focuses primarily on Alzheimer's disease (AD), aiming to improve early diagnosis, prognosis, and understanding of disease progression through biomarker discovery and neuroimaging. He has contributed to identifying novel cerebrospinal fluid biomarkers that complement established markers to better detect early-stage AD and predict cognitive decline. Perrin has also explored advanced imaging techniques, such as MRI-based brain age estimation using deep learning, to map neuroanatomic changes related to AD and mild cognitive impairment. Additionally, his work integrates multi-omics data and clinical information to uncover molecular profiles associated with AD progression and to enhance clinical trial design and therapeutic development.

Sandra E. Black's research focuses on neurodegenerative diseases, particularly Alzheimer's disease, frontotemporal dementia, and stroke-related cognitive decline. She has contributed to developing classification systems for primary progressive aphasia and explored data-driven methods to identify disease subtypes and progression patterns using advanced neuroimaging and machine learning techniques. Her work also includes the creation and validation of automated imaging tools for brain structure segmentation, such as hippocampus and white matter hyperintensity delineation, to improve diagnostic accuracy and tracking of brain atrophy. Additionally, she investigates modifiable risk factors connecting vascular health and dementia, aiming to support preventive strategies.

title: Professor
ai_summary: Jenny Benois-Pineau is a Professor at LABRI, University of Bordeaux, specializing in computer-aided diagnosis with a focus on Alzheimer's Disease (AD). Her research extensively explores the fusion of multiple brain imaging modalities, including structural MRI, diffusion tensor imaging, and functional MRI, utilizing deep learning techniques such as convolutional neural networks to improve early detection and classification of AD and Mild Cognitive Impairment. She also investigates cross-modal transfer learning, data augmentation, and multi-projection fusion methods to enhance diagnostic accuracy. Additionally, her work encompasses applying multimedia analysis and lifelog data for monitoring frailty and risk situations in elderly populations.

Dagoberto Cruz‐Sandoval's research focuses on the development and deployment of socially assistive robots to support people with dementia and mild cognitive impairment. His work involves designing conversational and exercise-coaching robots that facilitate therapeutic interventions such as cognitive stimulation, music therapy, and behavior management in clinical and home settings. He emphasizes human-centered design principles, incorporating conversational strategies, personalization, and caregiver input to enhance user engagement and acceptance. Additionally, his studies explore robotic support for goal-setting, eating behavior assistance, and long-term impact on quality of life for individuals with cognitive impairments.

title: Professor and Canada Research Chair in Robots for Society
ai_summary: Goldie Nejat is a Professor and Canada Research Chair in Robots for Society in the Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering at the University of Toronto. Her research focuses on the design and development of socially assistive robots that provide personalized cognitive and physical assistance to older adults and individuals with cognitive impairments. Nejat’s work includes creating human-like expressive robots that support activities of daily living such as meal eating, dressing, and cognitive engagement through adaptive learning architectures combining reinforcement and demonstration learning. She also explores the integration of emerging technologies like wearable sensors and large language models to enhance social human-robot interactions in healthcare settings.

Bruno Dubois is a researcher focused on Alzheimer's disease and related neurodegenerative disorders, emphasizing biomarker standardization, cognitive assessment, and precision medicine. His work includes developing standardized protocols for hippocampal volumetry, advancing computerized cognitive screening tools, and proposing brain health services aimed at primary and secondary dementia prevention. He also explores the integration of artificial intelligence and machine learning to improve diagnostic accuracy in clinical settings. Additionally, Dubois investigates the complex relationships between depression, cognitive impairment, and dementia risk, advocating for personalized approaches to diagnosis and treatment.

title: Adjunct Professor
org: The University of British Columbia Okanagan
unit: School of Health and Exercise Sciences
ai_summary: Jennifer Boger is an Adjunct Professor at the School of Health and Exercise Sciences at The University of British Columbia Okanagan. Her research focuses on the development and evaluation of assistive technologies, particularly for older adults with dementia, aiming to support independence in activities of daily living through innovative systems like AI-guided devices and ambient monitoring. She also explores interdisciplinary approaches to assistive technology design and the ethical considerations of AgeTech to enhance healthy aging. Additionally, her work includes the use of IoT, computer vision, and wearable sensors for monitoring physical activity, gait, and sleep patterns in aging populations.

org: Ollscoil na Gaillimhe – University of Galway
ai_summary: Sally Whelan's research focuses on the use of social and pet robots to support older adults, particularly those living with dementia, by addressing issues of loneliness, social isolation, and cognitive decline. Her work includes studying the MARIO companion robot, exploring its acceptability, engagement, and impact on quality of life, depression, social support, and resilience among people with dementia in various international settings. Additionally, she has investigated the usability and effects of low-cost robotic pets like the Joy for All cat through large-scale analysis of consumer reviews. Her studies emphasize user-led design, personalized applications, and the need for person-centered robotic solutions to enhance social connectedness and wellbeing in dementia care.

title: Director
unit: Geriatric Unit & Laboratory of Gerontology and Geriatrics, Department of Medical Sciences
ai_summary: Antonio Greco is Director of the Geriatric Unit & Laboratory of Gerontology and Geriatrics in the Department of Medical Sciences at Ospedale Casa Sollievo della Sofferenza. His research focuses on the application of information and communication technologies (ICT), social robots, and virtual tools to support elderly patients, particularly those with dementia and insomnia. He has been involved in projects developing and validating robotic companions like MARIO to enhance social engagement, cognitive assessment, and quality of life for older adults. Additionally, Greco explores methodological approaches for using technology to improve diagnosis, monitoring, and care delivery in geriatric populations, including during the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: Associate Professor
ai_summary: Panagiotis D. Bamidis is an Associate Professor at the School of Medicine, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, specializing in the development of ICT solutions for health, aging, and cognitive impairment. His research spans automated sleep stage classification using deep learning, innovative use of exergames and wireless EEG devices for health monitoring, and the design of smart living environments for older adults through co-creation and participatory methods. He has contributed to EU-funded projects focusing on digital platforms for monitoring quality of life in aging populations and cancer patients, as well as virtual coaching systems to promote active and healthy aging. His work also emphasizes the integration of multimodal data and digital biomarkers to support prediction, early diagnosis, and personalized care for cognitive disorders.

title: Co-Director
unit: Centre for Healthy Brain Ageing (CHeBA), School of Psychiatry
ai_summary: Perminder S. Sachdev is Co-Director of the Centre for Healthy Brain Ageing (CHeBA) at the School of Psychiatry, University of New South Wales. His research focuses on the neurobiological and clinical aspects of cognitive aging and dementia, particularly Alzheimer's disease. He employs advanced machine learning, neuroimaging, and lipidomics techniques to investigate biomarkers, genetic risk factors, and brain health dynamics related to cognitive decline, cerebral small vessel disease, and stroke outcomes. His work integrates multimodal data to develop predictive models for disease progression and aims to improve early detection and intervention strategies in neurodegenerative disorders.

Jeffrey Kaye's research focuses on Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and related neurodegenerative conditions, emphasizing early detection, biomarker identification, and disease progression prediction. He has developed integrative models using neuroimaging, cerebrospinal fluid proteomics, and digital biomarkers to improve diagnostic and prognostic accuracy, particularly in preclinical and mild cognitive impairment stages. His work also explores the ethical and practical implications of technology and artificial companions in dementia care, along with the role of innovation diplomacy in advancing global brain health. Overall, Kaye integrates clinical, technological, and policy perspectives to enhance understanding and management of cognitive decline and brain health.

title: H. L Eastlick Professor of Psychology
ai_summary: Maureen Schmitter-Edgecombe, H. L Eastlick Professor of Psychology at Washington State University, conducts research at the intersection of neuropsychology, aging, and smart home technologies. Her work focuses on developing and validating machine learning methods and pervasive sensing to monitor and assess functional health, cognitive status, and everyday activities in older adults, including those with mild cognitive impairment or dementia. She explores innovative approaches to detect early signs of cognitive decline and to forecast health outcomes using unobtrusive behavioral data collected in home environments. Additionally, her research examines the utility of technology-based neuropsychological assessments and automated interventions to support independent living and reduce caregiver burden.

David M. Holtzman's research focuses on the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying neurodegenerative diseases, particularly Alzheimer's disease (AD). His work explores key pathological features such as protein aggregation, synaptic dysfunction, and neuroinflammation, while identifying and validating biomarkers for early diagnosis and disease progression. He has investigated the propagation of tau pathology, the impact of neuronal activity on amyloid-beta dynamics, and the role of the gut microbiome in preclinical AD. Holtzman's studies also employ advanced imaging and proteomic approaches alongside machine learning to improve understanding and prediction of cognitive impairment in AD.

title: Assistant professor
ai_summary: Carlos Cruchaga is an Assistant Professor of Psychiatry at Washington University in Saint Louis whose research focuses on understanding aging and neurodegenerative diseases, particularly Alzheimer's disease (AD). He employs advanced proteomics, machine learning, and multi-omics approaches to identify biomarkers from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, and gut microbiome that predict organ-specific aging, AD progression, and cognitive decline. His work explores molecular mechanisms underlying tauopathies and synaptic dysfunction, aiming to improve early disease detection and prognosis. Cruchaga’s studies contribute to elucidating biological pathways and developing predictive models to enhance clinical outcomes in AD and related disorders.

org: Center for Scientific Research and Higher Education at Ensenada
ai_summary: Jesús Favela's research focuses on the development and application of socially assistive robots (SARs) to support people with dementia through non-pharmacological interventions. His work includes designing autonomous robots like Eva that facilitate cognitive stimulation, exercise, and eating behaviors by engaging users with personalized conversational strategies, music, and multimodal interaction. He employs human-centered design principles and machine learning techniques to tailor robot behaviors to individual needs, aiming to improve communication, reduce behavioral symptoms, and enhance the quality of life of dementia patients. Additionally, Favela has contributed to creating simulation tools to aid in therapy script development and training for SAR deployment.

title: CEO
ai_summary: Alex Zhavoronkov is the CEO of Research at Insilico Medicine, Inc., where he focuses on advancing aging research and longevity medicine through artificial intelligence (AI). His work includes developing deep learning aging clocks using diverse biological and psychological data to predict biological age, assess health trajectories, and identify novel therapeutic targets for age-related diseases. He explores AI-driven solutions such as blockchain-enabled personal health data ecosystems and large language models for drug discovery and biomarker development. Zhavoronkov also advocates for integrating aging as a diagnosable condition within medical classification systems to foster preventive and personalized longevity medicine.

Kaj Blennow is a researcher specializing in the molecular and clinical aspects of Alzheimer's disease and related dementias. His work focuses on identifying and validating cerebrospinal fluid and blood-based biomarkers to predict disease progression and differentiate Alzheimer's from other conditions. He integrates advanced techniques such as proteomics, machine learning, and neuroimaging to enhance understanding of neuroinflammation, neurodegeneration, and cognitive decline. Additionally, he contributes to the development of personalized medicine approaches and brain health services aimed at early risk assessment and prevention of dementia.

title: Researcher
unit: Scientific direction, Scientific and technological area
ai_summary: Roberta Bevilacqua is a researcher affiliated with the Scientific Direction and Scientific and Technological Area at INRCA-IRCCS. Her work focuses on developing and evaluating assistive technologies, including robotic systems, virtual coaching, and digital platforms, aimed at promoting active and healthy aging in older adults. She investigates user acceptance and the personalization of digital interventions to support autonomy, social engagement, cognitive function, and quality of life among older populations. Her research emphasizes multidisciplinary collaboration to integrate technology, behavioral insights, and healthcare needs for improved aging outcomes.

title: Hugh Monroe Wilson Professor of Radiology
ai_summary: Tammie L.S. Benzinger is the Hugh Monroe Wilson Professor of Radiology at the Mallinckrodt Institute of Radiology, Washington University in St. Louis. Her research focuses on imaging and biomarker studies of Alzheimer's disease (AD), particularly the use of PET and MRI techniques to examine tau pathology, amyloid deposition, and brain aging across preclinical and symptomatic stages of AD. She has explored the interplay between neuroimaging markers, cerebrospinal fluid measures, and the gut microbiome to improve prediction and understanding of AD progression. Her work also employs machine learning to analyze complex biomarker profiles to identify critical factors linked to cognitive decline in AD.

Álvaro Pascual-Leone's research centers on noninvasive brain stimulation techniques such as transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) and their applications in brain health, cognitive function, and recovery after neurological injuries like stroke and traumatic brain injury. He has contributed to understanding brain plasticity mechanisms across the lifespan and developed innovative digital tools, including machine learning-based assessments, to detect and monitor cognitive impairment. Pascual-Leone is also involved in large-scale initiatives like the Barcelona Brain Health Initiative, focusing on lifestyle and biological factors influencing brain health and personalized interventions supported by technology. His work spans from clinical neurorehabilitation to advancing digital neuropsychological assessments and population-based brain health research.

title: Associate Director
ai_summary: James B. Rowe is Associate Director of Experimental Medicine at Dementias Platform UK, focusing on neurodegenerative dementias such as frontotemporal dementia, Alzheimer's disease, and atypical parkinsonian syndromes. His work employs advanced machine learning techniques and neuroimaging modalities, including MRI and magnetoencephalography (MEG), to identify distinct disease subtypes, progression patterns, and early physiological changes. Rowe's research emphasizes the characterization of brain network disruptions and the development of data-driven tools for improved diagnosis, patient stratification, and understanding of disease mechanisms. Additionally, he contributes to creating large-scale, accessible datasets and secure platforms to support collaborative dementia research.

Kenneth Rockwood's research focuses on frailty, aging, and dementia, with significant contributions to the development of practical clinical tools like the Clinical Frailty Scale and the Frailty Index to predict adverse health outcomes in older adults. He has explored the biology and epidemiology of frailty, emphasizing its dynamic nature and relationship with mortality and comorbidity. His work also integrates advanced machine learning and artificial intelligence techniques to improve dementia phenotyping, staging, and prediction of survival, supporting personalized care approaches. Additionally, he is involved in large collaborative networks and computational modeling efforts aimed at transforming dementia research through multi-disciplinary data integration.

title: professor of clinical neurophysiology
ai_summary: Cornelis J. Stam is a professor of clinical neurophysiology and neurology at Amsterdam UMC Location VUmc. His research focuses on the study of brain network organization and functional connectivity in various neurological disorders, including Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease, dementia with Lewy bodies, low-grade glioma, and fragile X syndrome. He employs advanced neurophysiological techniques such as EEG and magnetoencephalography, combined with graph theory and multiplex network analysis, to investigate the alterations in brain networks and their relationship with cognitive and clinical symptoms. His work also extends to exploring biomarkers for disease progression and the effects of interventions on synaptic function and network integrity.

Reisa A. Sperling’s research focuses on the early detection and characterization of Alzheimer’s disease (AD), particularly its preclinical stage before cognitive symptoms emerge. Her work emphasizes the use of imaging biomarkers such as amyloid PET and MRI to improve diagnosis and track disease progression, alongside developing standardized methods for measuring these biomarkers. She has also investigated the association of neuropsychiatric symptoms like loneliness and depressive symptoms with amyloid pathology in cognitively normal older adults. Additionally, Sperling has contributed to advancing machine learning approaches for earlier detection of cognitive decline and optimizing clinical trial recruitment through predictive algorithms.

title: Professor
ai_summary: Stephen H. Scott is a Professor in Biomedical and Molecular Sciences at Queen's University, specializing in the use of robotic technologies to objectively assess and rehabilitate sensorimotor and cognitive impairments in neurological disorders such as stroke, traumatic brain injury, Parkinson's disease, and multiple sclerosis. His research utilizes robotic systems like the Kinarm exoskeleton to quantify upper limb motor function, proprioception, and cognitive processes, enabling detailed evaluation of deficits and monitoring recovery over time. He has developed robotic tasks that facilitate rapid, precise assessment and targeted therapy, improving understanding of impairments and guiding rehabilitation strategies. Additionally, his work explores how robotic measures correlate with traditional clinical assessments, providing complementary insights into neurological function.

title: Senior Research Fellow
ai_summary: Janice M. Ranson is a Senior Research Fellow at the College of Medicine and Health, University of Exeter, specializing in the application of artificial intelligence and machine learning to dementia research. Her work focuses on improving dementia risk prediction, biomarker discovery, and the development of Brain Health Services aimed at early intervention and personalized risk reduction. She investigates the use of advanced analytic approaches to enhance diagnosis, prognosis, and prevention strategies by integrating multimodal data including genetics, neuroimaging, and clinical measures. Ranson emphasizes methodological rigor, data diversity, and interdisciplinary collaboration to advance precision medicine in neurodegenerative diseases.

title: Professor
ai_summary: Young Chul Youn is a Professor of Neurology at Chung-Ang University Hospital whose research focuses on applying machine learning and deep learning techniques to electroencephalogram (EEG) data for diagnosing cognitive impairments and neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's disease. His work includes developing EEG-based biomarkers and autonomous diagnostic models to detect mild cognitive impairment, dementia, and brain amyloid pathology with high accuracy and efficiency. He has contributed to designing new datasets and end-to-end deep neural networks for automatic brain disorder classification, as well as validating quantitative EEG biomarkers against established clinical standards like amyloid PET scans. His research aims to provide cost-effective, accessible, and reliable screening tools to support early diagnosis and monitoring of neurological conditions.

Laurel D. Riek's research focuses on the development and design of socially assistive robots to support healthcare, particularly for older adults and individuals with cognitive impairments such as dementia and mild cognitive impairment. She explores collaborative, user-centered approaches to create robots that aid in neurorehabilitation, caregiving, and daily activities like eating, emphasizing autonomy, personalization, and long-term engagement. Riek also investigates how shifting perspectives on aging and concepts like wisdom can inform more supportive and empowering human-robot interactions. Her work bridges clinical needs and robotics technology to enhance well-being and care delivery in home and community settings.

title: Professor
ai_summary: David A. Wolk is a Professor in the Neurology Department at the University of Pennsylvania specializing in neuroimaging and neurodegenerative diseases, particularly Alzheimer’s disease (AD). His research employs advanced MRI techniques, machine learning, and deep learning to characterize brain atrophy patterns, cerebral blood flow, and pathological heterogeneity associated with AD and typical aging. He has developed novel quantitative imaging biomarkers for early diagnosis, progression tracking, and subtype differentiation of cognitive impairment and dementia. His work also integrates multimodal data including genetics, cerebrospinal fluid biomarkers, and histopathology to improve understanding of disease mechanisms and support precision diagnostics and targeted clinical trials.

Anne-Sophie Rigaud is a researcher specializing in the intersection of aging, cognitive impairment, and assistive technologies. Her work explores older adults' acceptance and use of robots and ICTs designed to support independence, social connectivity, and well-being, particularly among those with mild cognitive impairment and dementia. She has investigated the usability, attitudes, and barriers related to robotic and virtual coaching interventions, as well as the effectiveness of social robots in reducing apathy and social isolation. Additionally, she has contributed to developing AI-based methods for early detection of Alzheimer's disease through behavioral data such as handwriting analysis.

Kun Ho Lee's research focuses on the application of machine learning and deep learning techniques for the diagnosis and staging of Alzheimer's disease (AD) and mild cognitive impairment (MCI). His work extensively utilizes neuroimaging modalities such as structural and functional MRI, emphasizing regions like the hippocampus and developing models that extract volumetric and connectivity features. He also explores non-invasive approaches involving eye movement data, gait analysis, and bioimpedance combined with cognitive scores for early and cost-effective screening. Additionally, Lee has contributed to enhancing genetic studies of AD by integrating machine learning to increase statistical power in genome-wide association studies.

Goo-Rak Kwon's research focuses on the early diagnosis and progression prediction of Alzheimer's disease (AD) and mild cognitive impairment (MCI) using advanced neuroimaging techniques and machine learning. His work often integrates multimodal biomarkers such as structural MRI, PET scans, cerebrospinal fluid protein levels, and genetic data, applying methods like convolutional neural networks (CNNs), Vision Transformers (ViTs), and deep neural networks to enhance classification accuracy. He also explores self-supervised learning and explainable AI to improve model interpretability and reduce reliance on large labeled datasets. Overall, his studies contribute to developing computational tools for more accurate and early detection of AD, aiming to support timely intervention strategies.

title: Canada Research Chair in Senior Care/ Associate Professor
ai_summary: Lillian Hung is the Canada Research Chair in Senior Care and an Associate Professor in Nursing at The University of British Columbia. Her research focuses on the integration of technology, particularly social and telepresence robots, in dementia care within hospital and long-term care settings. She investigates the experiences and perspectives of patients with dementia, their families, and frontline staff to inform ethical and effective implementation of robotic technologies. Her work also emphasizes co-design and active involvement of patient and family partners in research to improve care practices for older adults.

Andrea Iaboni's research focuses on improving the health and well-being of older adults with dementia, particularly those residing in long-term care settings. Their work integrates technology, such as computer vision, wearable sensors, and machine learning, to monitor and assess gait, fall risk, parkinsonism severity, and behavioral symptoms of dementia. Iaboni also investigates strategies to enhance social connection and deliver technology-enabled recreational activities to support mental health and quality of life in this population. This body of work emphasizes personalized, privacy-conscious approaches to facilitate early intervention and tailored care for individuals with cognitive impairment.

title: Professor
org: Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics
ai_summary: Daoqiang Zhang is a Professor of Computer Science at Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics whose research focuses on applying deep learning and machine learning techniques to neuroimaging analysis for brain disorder diagnosis. His work encompasses developing advanced neural network models, such as spatial-temporal convolutional-recurrent networks and 3D residual attention networks, to improve early detection and progression prediction of Alzheimer's disease and mild cognitive impairment using MRI and fMRI data. He has also contributed to methods that integrate multiple network properties for better classification and proposed domain transfer learning to utilize auxiliary data effectively. Additionally, Zhang has worked on efficient parallel training approaches for deep neural networks, enhancing computational performance in medical image analysis.

John E. Morley's research focuses on geriatric medicine, particularly the identification, assessment, and management of frailty and related geriatric syndromes such as sarcopenia, cognitive impairment, and anorexia of aging. He has contributed to developing practical tools like the Rapid Geriatric Assessment, enabling primary care providers to screen for these conditions efficiently without requiring geriatric specialists. Morley has also explored the improvement of care quality in nursing homes and the integration of biological aging knowledge to advance targeted interventions for frailty. Additionally, his work includes investigations into the potential role of robotic caregivers and the promotion of interdisciplinary collaboration in aging research.
